Refrigerate for at least 1 hour before serving. Cut into squares to serve.

recipes.name: Vegetable Relish Salad
ingredients: 1 can (15 oz) White sweet corn (shoe peg style) (drained)
1 can (14.5 oz) French style green beans (reserve 2 tablespoons liquid before draining)
1/4 cup Vegetable or salad oil (for marinade)
2 tablespoons Reserved green bean juice (from canned beans)
instructions: Before draining the green beans, reserve 2 tablespoons of the liquid from the can.
Drain all canned vegetables in a colander. You can save the remaining vegetable juices for soup stock if desired.
In a large bowl, combine the drained corn, green beans, peas, chopped onion, celery, green bell pepper, and pimento.
In a small saucepan, combine the sugar, oil, vinegar, salt, pepper, and reserved green bean juice.
Bring the marinade to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring to dissolve the sugar.
Pour the hot marinade over the vegetables and stir gently to coat everything evenly.
Cover and refrigerate overnight (at least 8 hours) to allow the flavors to blend.
Stir before serving. Serve cold as a side dish or relish.
This salad keeps well in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.

recipes.name: Carrot Soup
ingredients: to taste Salt and white pepper
instructions: In a large heavy saucepan or Dutch oven, melt 2 tablespoons of unsalted butter over medium heat.
Add the chopped onion and celery. Cook, stirring occasionally, for about 5 minutes, until softened but not browned.
Stir in the chopped carrots, chicken broth, tomato paste, and raw rice. Bring to a simmer.
Reduce heat and simmer gently for 30 minutes, or until the carrots and rice are very tender.
Working in batches if necessary, puree the soup in a blender or food processor until completely smooth. Alternatively, use an immersion blender directly in the pot.
Return the pureed soup to the pot (if using a blender). Stir in the evaporated milk and remaining tablespoon of unsalted butter.
Season with salt and white pepper to taste. Reheat gently over low heat; do not boil.
Ladle into bowls and garnish with carrot curls, if desired. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Hearty Chowder
ingredients: 1 clove Garlic (minced, or 1/8 tsp garlic powder)
to taste Salt and freshly ground black pepper
instructions: Bring a pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add the diced carrots and cook for about 5 minutes. Add the cubed potatoes and cook for another 5–7 minutes, until both are just tender. Drain and set aside.
In a large heavy pot or Dutch oven, melt the unsalted butter over medium-low heat.
Add the cubed turkey ham and minced garlic. Cook, stirring occasionally, for about 5 minutes.
Stir in the celery, broccoli (if using), and chopped onion. Continue cooking over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are soft but not browned (about 5–7 minutes).
Sprinkle the flour over the vegetable and ham mixture. Stir well to coat everything evenly, and cook for 1–2 minutes to remove the raw flour taste.
Gradually pour in the milk, whisking or stirring constantly to prevent lumps. Cook over medium heat, stirring frequently, until the mixture is smooth and begins to thicken.
Add the cooked potatoes and carrots. Stir gently to combine.
Season with salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer gently for about 10 minutes to let the flavors meld. Do not let the chowder boil, or the milk may curdle.
Serve hot, with crackers or crusty bread on the side.

recipes.name: Divinity
ingredients: 1 tablespoon Flavoring extract (vanilla, almond, or your choice)
1 cup Pecans or walnuts (broken into small pieces)
instructions: Line a baking sheet with wax paper or parchment, or coat an 8×8-inch pan with nonstick spray.
In a heavy 2-quart saucepan, combine the sugar, corn syrup, and water. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the sugar dissolves.
Once the sugar is dissolved, stop stirring. Continue cooking without stirring until the mixture reaches 265°F (hard-ball stage) on a candy thermometer. This will take 10-15 minutes.
While the syrup cooks, beat the egg whites in a large bowl with an electric mixer on high speed until stiff peaks form.
When the syrup reaches 265°F, remove it from heat. With the mixer running on medium speed, slowly pour the hot syrup in a thin stream into the beaten egg whites. Be careful—the mixture is very hot.
Continue beating at medium speed until the mixture becomes thick and starts to lose its gloss, about 5-8 minutes.
Stir in the flavoring extract and chopped nuts by hand.
Quickly drop spoonfuls of the mixture onto the prepared wax paper, or spread into the prepared pan and cut into squares when cool.
Let cool completely at room temperature. Store in an airtight container.

recipes.name: Fudge (Cocoa Nut)
instructions: Line an 8×8-inch pan with foil or parchment, or coat it with nonstick spray.
In a heavy 2-quart saucepan, combine the sugar, cocoa powder, and milk. Stir over medium heat until the sugar dissolves and the mixture is smooth.

Once the sugar is dissolved, clip a candy thermometer to the side of the pan. Stop stirring and cook without stirring over very low heat until the mixture reaches soft-ball stage (234-238°F). This will take 20-30 minutes.
Remove from heat and add the unsalted butter. Do not stir—just let it melt on top.
Let the mixture cool undisturbed to lukewarm (about 110°F), about 30-45 minutes.
Add the vanilla and beat vigorously with a wooden spoon until the fudge thickens and loses its gloss, about 5-10 minutes.
Stir in the chopped nuts.
Quickly pour the fudge into the prepared pan and smooth the top.
Let cool completely, then cut into squares. Store in an airtight container.

recipes.name: Peanut Brittle (Munching)
instructions: Coat a large rimmed baking sheet with nonstick spray or use a nonstick baking mat.
In a microwave-safe 1 1/2-quart or 2-quart glass bowl, stir together the sugar, corn syrup, salt, and peanuts until well combined.
Microwave on HIGH for 4 minutes.
Remove and stir well. Microwave on HIGH for an additional 3-5 minutes, until the mixture turns light golden brown and the peanuts are toasted. Watch carefully to avoid burning.
Carefully remove from microwave (mixture will be extremely hot). Stir in the unsalted butter and vanilla until well blended.
Microwave on HIGH for 1-2 minutes more, until the syrup is very hot and the peanuts are golden.
Immediately stir in the baking soda—the mixture will foam up dramatically. Stir quickly until well mixed and foamy.
Quickly pour the hot mixture onto the prepared baking sheet and spread as thin as possible with a greased spatula.
Let cool completely, about 30-60 minutes.
Break into pieces and store in an airtight container. For Pecan Brittle, substitute 1 1/2 cups pecan halves for peanuts and coconut extract for vanilla.

recipes.name: Pralines, Old Fashioned
ingredients: 2 cups Pecan halves or pieces (coarsely chopped)
instructions: Line 2 baking sheets with wax paper or parchment, and lightly coat with nonstick spray.
In a large, heavy saucepan (at least 3-quart), combine the granulated sugar, brown sugar, pecans, buttermilk, unsalted butter, and salt.
Cook over low heat, stirring gently, until both sugars dissolve completely.
Cover the pan and cook over medium heat for 2-3 minutes. This creates steam that washes sugar crystals off the sides of the pan.
Uncover and clip a candy thermometer to the side. Cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture reaches soft-ball stage (234-238°F). This will take about 10-15 minutes.
Remove from heat. Stir in the baking soda and vanilla—the mixture will foam up.
Beat vigorously with a wooden spoon until the mixture begins to thicken and lose its gloss, about 2-3 minutes.
Working quickly, drop tablespoonfuls of the mixture onto the prepared wax paper, spacing them about 2 inches apart.
Let the pralines cool completely until firm, about 30 minutes. Store in an airtight container with wax paper between layers.

recipes.name: Fudge (Plain)
instructions: Lightly coat an 8x8-inch baking pan with nonstick cooking spray or line with parchment paper.
In a heavy-bottomed saucepan, combine the sugar, cocoa powder, salt, and milk. Stir well to mix.
Place the saucepan over medium-low heat. Stir constantly until the sugar is completely dissolved and the mixture is smooth.

Once the sugar dissolves, stop stirring. Attach a candy thermometer to the side of the pan. Continue cooking without stirring until the mixture reaches the soft-ball stage (234-238°F). This may take 15-20 minutes. Be patient and do not stir during this time, or the fudge may crystallize.
When the mixture reaches the soft-ball stage, remove from heat immediately. Stir in the unsalted butter and oil.
Let the mixture cool, undisturbed, to lukewarm (about 110°F). This may take 30-45 minutes. Do not stir during cooling, or the fudge may become grainy.
Once lukewarm, add the vanilla extract. Beat vigorously with a wooden spoon until the mixture thickens and loses its glossy appearance. This can take 5-10 minutes of beating.
Quickly pour the fudge into the prepared pan and spread evenly with a spatula.
Let the fudge cool completely at room temperature until firm, about 2 hours.
Cut into 1-inch squares. Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 weeks.

recipes.name: Apple Cake
ingredients: 3 cups, peeled and diced Fresh apples (about 3 medium apples)
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and flour a 9x13-inch baking pan.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt.
In a large bowl, beat the eggs. Add both sugars, the oil, and vanilla, and mix until well combined.
Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until just combined. The batter will be very thick and stiff.
Fold in the diced apples and chopped pecans, distributing them evenly.
Spread the thick batter into the prepared pan, smoothing the top as well as you can.
Bake for 30–40 minutes, or until the top is golden brown and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool in the pan on a wire rack. Serve warm or at room temperature, plain or with a dusting of powdered sugar or a scoop of vanilla ice cream.

recipes.name: Deluxe White Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and flour three 9-inch round cake pans, or line the bottoms with parchment.
In a large bowl, sift together the cake flour, 1 cup of the sugar, the baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.
In a separate bowl, beat the egg whites until foamy. Add the cream of tartar and continue beating until soft peaks form.
Gradually add the remaining 1/2 cup of sugar to the egg whites, beating until the meringue is stiff and glossy. Set aside.
In another bowl, whisk together the oil, buttermilk, and vanilla until well combined.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients all at once and beat with a mixer on medium speed until you have a smooth batter.
Using a rubber spatula, gently fold the meringue into the batter in three additions, making sure to scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl for even mixing.
Divide the batter evenly among the three prepared pans.
Bake for 30–35 minutes, or until the cakes are just firm to the touch and starting to pull away from the sides of the pans. A toothpick inserted in the center should come out clean.
Let the cakes cool in the pans for 5 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely before frosting.

recipes.name: Frosted Carrot Cake
ingredients: 3/4 cup Eggs or large eggs (about 3 large eggs)
8 oz can in juice, well drained Crushed pineapple
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Coat a 13x9x2-inch baking pan with nonstick spray.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, whole wheat flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the brown sugar, eggs or large eggs, buttermilk, oil, and vanilla. Beat at medium speed until smooth.
Add the drained pineapple, grated carrots, and raisins to the wet mixture and stir to combine.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and beat just until well blended and no dry pockets remain.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan and spread evenly.
Bake for 30–35 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean and the top springs back when lightly touched.
Cool the cake completely in the pan on a wire rack.
Once cooled, spread Orange-Cream Cheese Frosting evenly over the top of the cake.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour before serving. Cut into squares to serve.

recipes.name: Bakeless Fruit Cake
ingredients: 1/2 pound, finely crushed Vanilla wafers (about 3 cups crushed)
1/2 pound, finely crushed Graham crackers (about 3 cups crushed)
6 oz, drained and chopped Maraschino cherries
instructions: Reserve 40 whole pecan halves for decorating the top. Coarsely chop the remaining pecans.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the crushed vanilla wafers and crushed graham crackers.
Add the raisins, chopped dates, chopped cherries, and chopped pecans. Mix well to distribute evenly.
Pour in the sweetened condensed milk and bourbon (or rum). Stir thoroughly until the mixture is well combined and holds together.
Line a 9x5x3-inch loaf pan with plastic wrap or waxed paper, leaving enough overhang to cover the top.
Spoon the mixture into the prepared pan and press down very firmly and evenly to compact it.
Arrange the reserved pecan halves decoratively on top, pressing them lightly into the surface.
Fold the excess wrap over the top to cover completely.
Refrigerate overnight, or at least 8 hours, to set.
To serve, unwrap and invert onto a serving platter. Remove the wrap and slice with a sharp knife.
Serve slices plain or with a dollop of whipped cream. Store wrapped in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

recipes.name: Hot Water Gingerbread
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking pan or coat with nonstick spray.
In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, ginger, cinnamon, and salt.
In a separate large bowl, combine the molasses, sugar, and melted unsalted butter or butter. Mix well.
Add the egg to the molasses mixture and beat until smooth.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture and stir until just combined.
Carefully stir in the boiling water. The batter will be thin—this is correct.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan.
Bake for 45-50 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean and the top springs back when lightly touched.
Cool in the pan on a wire rack for at least 15 minutes.
Serve warm or at room temperature, plain or with whipped cream or lemon sauce.

recipes.name: Spice Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9-inch square or round cake pan or an 8-inch cast iron skillet.
In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, cocoa powder, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger, and salt.
In a separate bowl or measuring cup, combine the vegetable oil and water.
Pour the liquid mixture into the dry ingredients and stir just until combined.
Fold in the raisins.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan.
Bake for 30-40 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool in the pan on a wire rack.
Serve plain, as Grandmother did, or dust lightly with powdered sugar if desired.
Note: For a Christmas fruitcake variation, add 1/2 cup chopped nuts and 1/2 cup chopped candied fruit or peel to the batter.
notes: Grandmother Walters used 1/2 cup of shortening, probably lard. Grandmother baked this cake in a heavy cake pan or an iron skillet. Eggs WERE NOT USED. Cake was not iced.

recipes.name: Old Fashioned Jelly Roll
ingredients: 3/4 cup, sifted Cake flour or all-purpose flour
3/4 to 1 cup Jelly or jam (any flavor)
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Grease a 15x10-inch jelly roll pan, line with parchment paper, and grease the paper.
In a small bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.
Place the eggs in a large heatproof bowl. Set the bowl over a pot of simmering water (double boiler method).
Beat the eggs with an electric mixer while gradually adding the sugar. Continue beating over the hot water until the mixture is very thick, pale, and tripled in volume (about 5-7 minutes).
Remove the bowl from the heat.
Gently fold in the vanilla extract.
Sift the flour mixture over the egg mixture in three additions, folding gently after each addition until just combined. Do not overmix.
If making a richer version, fold in 2 tablespoons melted unsalted butter or butter at this point.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan and spread evenly to the edges.
Bake for 12-13 minutes, until the cake is golden and springs back when lightly touched.
While the cake bakes, lay out a clean kitchen towel and dust it generously with confectioners' sugar.
When the cake is done, immediately run a knife around the edges and invert the cake onto the sugared towel.
Carefully peel off the parchment paper. Trim any crisp edges with a sharp knife.
Starting from a short end, roll the cake up in the towel while it's still warm. Let cool completely on a wire rack, seam-side down.
Once cooled, gently unroll the cake and spread evenly with your favorite jelly or jam.
Re-roll the cake without the towel, and place seam-side down on a serving platter.
Dust with additional confectioners' sugar before slicing and serving.

recipes.name: Holiday Jam Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 300°F (150°C). Line the bottom of a 10-inch tube pan with parchment or heavy brown paper, then grease and flour the pan and paper well.
In a large bowl, cream together the unsalted butter or butter and sugar until light and fluffy.
If using whole eggs, separate them. Beat the egg yolks (or use large eggs) until thick and pale, then add to the creamed mixture and beat well.
In a small bowl, dissolve the baking soda in the buttermilk. Add this to the creamed mixture and beat until combined.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, and allspice.
Alternately add the dry ingredients and the blackberry jam to the batter, beginning and ending with the dry ingredients. Mix just until combined after each addition.
If using whole eggs, beat the egg whites in a clean bowl until stiff peaks form. Gently fold the beaten egg whites into the batter by hand.
In a small bowl, toss the pecans, raisins, and dates with 2-3 tablespoons of flour to coat. Fold the floured fruit and nuts into the batter.
Pour the batter into the prepared tube pan and smooth the top.
Bake for 3 to 3 1/2 hours, or until a toothpick or broom straw inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool in the pan for 15 minutes, then invert onto a wire rack to cool completely.
When completely cool, wrap the cake in a bourbon-, brandy-, or sherry-soaked cloth, or store in an airtight tin with apple slices to keep it moist.
This cake improves with age and will keep in a cool place for up to 6 weeks.

recipes.name: Cocoanut Cake
ingredients: 1 recipe Deluxe White Cake (or your favorite white cake, baked in two 9-inch round pans and cooled)
1/2 cup (1 stick) Butter (softened to room temperature)
2 to 2 1/2 cups Sweetened shredded coconut (or unsweetened if preferred)
instructions: Bake the Deluxe White Cake (or your favorite white cake recipe) in two greased and floured 9-inch round cake pans according to the recipe directions. Let cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then turn out onto wire racks to cool completely.
While the cakes cool, prepare the buttercream icing: In a large bowl, beat the softened butter or unsalted butter with an electric mixer until creamy.
Gradually add the sifted confectioners' sugar, about 1 cup at a time, beating on low speed after each addition.
Add the milk and vanilla extract. Beat on medium-high speed for 2–3 minutes until the icing is light, fluffy, and spreadable. If the icing is too thick, add a little more milk, 1 teaspoon at a time.
Place one cake layer on a serving plate or cake stand. Spread about 1/2 cup of the icing evenly over the top.
Sprinkle about 1/2 to 3/4 cup of the shredded coconut over the icing on the first layer.
Carefully place the second cake layer on top, pressing gently to adhere.
Frost the top of the cake with a generous layer of icing, then frost the sides, using an offset spatula or butter knife for a smooth finish.

While the icing is still soft, gently press the remaining shredded coconut onto the top and sides of the cake, covering it completely. You may need to work in sections and press the coconut gently with your hands.
Refrigerate the cake for at least 1 hour before serving to let the icing set.
Store leftover cake covered in the refrigerator for up to 4 days. Bring to room temperature before serving for best flavor and texture.

recipes.name: Crumble Cake (Krümelkuchen)
ingredients: 2 large Eggs (for crust, or 1/2 cup large eggs)
2 large Eggs (for crumble topping, or 1/2 cup large eggs)
12 tablespoons (1 1/2 sticks) Butter (for crumble topping, softened)
2 large Eggs (for binder, or 1/2 cup large eggs)
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly grease six 8-inch pie plates or cake pans.

Prepare the crust: In a large bowl, whisk together 2 cups flour, 2 tsp baking powder, and 1/4 tsp salt. Add the melted unsalted butter, 2/3 cup sugar, 2 eggs (or substitute), and 1/4 cup milk. Mix well until a soft dough forms.
Divide the dough into 6 equal portions. Roll out each portion on a lightly floured surface to fit an 8-inch pie plate, bringing the dough about 3/4 inch up the sides. Press into the prepared pans.
Prepare the crumble topping: In a medium bowl, combine 2 cups sugar, 1 tsp vanilla, 2 eggs (or substitute), 12 tbsp softened unsalted butter, and 2 tsp baking powder. Mix well.
Gradually work in 2 1/2 cups flour, mixing and rubbing with your fingers until crumbles form. The crumbles should be random in size, with the largest about the size of a blueberry.
Prepare the binder: In a small bowl, whisk together 2 eggs (or substitute), 1/4 cup milk, 1 tsp vanilla, and 1 tsp sugar until well combined.
Brush or spoon about 4 teaspoons of the binder mixture evenly over each crust.
Distribute the crumbles evenly over the 6 crusts, dividing them as equally as possible.
Bake for 20-30 minutes, or until the cakes are nicely browned and the crumbles are golden and crisp.
Cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then carefully transfer to a wire rack. Serve warm or at room temperature. These cakes are wonderful with coffee or tea!

recipes.name: Apple Pie
ingredients: 4-5 medium Granny Smith or cooking apples (about 6 cups sliced)
3/4 to 1 cup Granulated sugar (adjust based on apple tartness)
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
Peel, core, and dice the apples into bite-sized pieces. You should have about 6 cups of diced apples, generously filling the pie crust.
In a large bowl, combine the diced apples with the sugar, cornstarch, and cinnamon. Toss until the apples are evenly coated.
Place one pie crust into a 9-inch pie pan. Pour the apple mixture into the crust, spreading it evenly. If desired, drizzle the melted unsalted butter over the top of the apples.
Cover with the second pie crust. Trim and crimp the edges to seal. Use a knife to cut several small slits or poke holes in the top crust to allow steam to escape.
Place the pie on a baking sheet to catch any drips. Bake at 400°F for 15 minutes.
Reduce the oven temperature to 350°F (175°C) and continue baking for 45-50 minutes, or until the crust is golden brown and the filling is bubbling.
To test doneness, insert a fork through one of the slits to check if the apples are tender.
Cool on a wire rack for at least 2 hours before slicing. Serve warm or at room temperature, optionally with vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.

recipes.name: Pie Crust
recipes.servings: Makes 2 single crusts or 1 double crust (8-9 inch)
ingredients: 1 tablespoon (optional) Granulated sugar (for a slightly sweet crust)
4-6 tablespoons Cold milk (use as needed for consistency)
instructions: In a medium bowl, sift together the flour, sugar (if using), salt, and baking soda.
In a small bowl, whisk together the vegetable oil and 4 tablespoons of cold milk with a rotary beater or hand mixer until the mixture is emulsified and has a milky appearance.
Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients and pour in the oil-milk mixture all at once.
Using a fork, gently stir the mixture, working from the center outward, until it begins to come together. Add 1-2 more tablespoons of milk if the dough seems too dry.
Use your hands to gently gather the dough into a ball. Do not overwork or add extra flour.
Divide the dough in half if making two single crusts.
Place one portion of dough between two sheets of waxed paper or parchment paper. Roll out to about 1/8-inch thickness and to fit your pie pan (9-10 inches in diameter).
Carefully peel off the top sheet of paper, then invert the crust into a lightly greased pie pan. Peel off the remaining paper.
Gently press the crust into the pan and trim the edges. Crimp or flute the edge as desired.
For a pre-baked crust: Prick the bottom and sides with a fork. Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 10-12 minutes, or until lightly golden.
For an unbaked crust: Fill and bake according to your pie recipe directions.
Repeat with the second portion of dough if making a two-crust pie.

recipes.name: Chocolate Cream Pie
ingredients: 1 2/3 cups (for 9-inch) Granulated sugar (reduce to 1 1/4 cups for 8-inch, 5/8 cup for 6-inch)
2/3 teaspoon (for 9-inch) Salt (reduce to 1/2 tsp for 8-inch, 1/3 tsp for 6-inch)
2 2/3 tablespoons (for 9-inch) Cornstarch (reduce to 2 tbsp for 8-inch, 1 1/3 tbsp for 6-inch)
6 tablespoons (for 9-inch) Unsweetened cocoa powder (reduce to 4 tbsp for 8-inch, 2 tbsp for 6-inch)
1 1/3 tablespoons (for 9-inch) All purpose flour (reduce to 1 tbsp for 8-inch, 1/2 tbsp for 6-inch)
2 2/3 cups (for 9-inch) Milk (reduce to 2 cups for 8-inch, 1 1/3 cups for 6-inch; 2% or whole)
3/4 cup (for 9-inch) Large Eggs (reduce to 1/2 cup for 8-inch, 1/4 cup for 6-inch; or use 3 egg yolks for 9-inch)
2 teaspoons (for 9-inch) Butter (reduce to 1 1/2 tsp for 8-inch, 1 tsp for 6-inch)
1 1/3 teaspoons (for 9-inch) Vanilla extract (reduce to 1 tsp for 8-inch, 1/2 tsp for 6-inch)
1 (9-inch, 8-inch, or 6-inch) Baked pie shell (fully baked and cooled)
as desired Meringue or whipped cream topping
instructions: Fill the bottom of a double boiler with water and bring to a simmer.
In the top of the double boiler (off the heat), whisk together the sugar, salt, cornstarch, cocoa powder, and flour until well combined and lump-free.
Gradually whisk in the milk until the mixture is smooth.

Place the top of the double boiler over the simmering water. Cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture comes to a boil and thickens, about 8–10 minutes. Let it boil gently for 3 minutes, continuing to stir.

In a small bowl, lightly beat the large eggs (or egg yolks). Slowly whisk about 1/2 cup of the hot chocolate mixture into the egg to temper it, then pour the tempered egg back into the double boiler, whisking constantly.
Cook over the simmering water for an additional 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the filling is thick and glossy.
Remove from heat and stir in the unsalted butter or butter until melted and fully incorporated.
Let the filling cool for about 10–15 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent a skin from forming. When slightly cooled, stir in the vanilla extract.
Pour the chocolate filling into the cooled, baked pie shell. Smooth the top with a spatula.

If topping with meringue: Spread the meringue over the filling while the filling is still warm, sealing the edges to the crust. Bake at 300°F (150°C) for 15–20 minutes until the meringue is lightly golden. Let cool completely before slicing.
If topping with whipped cream: Refrigerate the pie until fully set (at least 3 hours or overnight), then top with whipped cream just before serving.
Store leftovers covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

recipes.name: Vanilla Cream Pie
ingredients: 2/3 cup (for 9-inch) Granulated sugar (reduce to 1/2 cup for 8-inch, 1/3 cup for 6-inch)
2/3 teaspoon (for 9-inch) Salt (reduce to 1/2 tsp for 8-inch, 1/3 tsp for 6-inch)
2 2/3 tablespoons (for 9-inch) Cornstarch (reduce to 2 tbsp for 8-inch, 1 1/3 tbsp for 6-inch)
1 1/3 tablespoons (for 9-inch) All purpose flour (reduce to 1 tbsp for 8-inch, 1/2 tbsp for 6-inch)
2 2/3 cups (for 9-inch) Milk (reduce to 2 cups for 8-inch, 1 1/3 cups for 6-inch; 2% or whole)
3/4 cup (for 9-inch) Large Eggs (reduce to 1/2 cup for 8-inch, 1/4 cup for 6-inch; or use 3 egg yolks for 9-inch)
2 teaspoons (for 9-inch) Butter (reduce to 1 1/2 tsp for 8-inch, 1 tsp for 6-inch)
1 1/3 teaspoons (for 9-inch) Vanilla extract (reduce to 1 tsp for 8-inch, 1/2 tsp for 6-inch)
1 (9-inch, 8-inch, or 6-inch) Baked pie shell (fully baked and cooled)
as desired Meringue or whipped cream topping
instructions: Fill the bottom of a double boiler with water and bring to a simmer.
In the top of the double boiler (off the heat), whisk together the sugar, salt, cornstarch, and flour until well combined and lump-free.
Gradually whisk in the milk until the mixture is smooth.

Place the top of the double boiler over the simmering water. Cook, stirring constantly, until the mixture comes to a boil and thickens, about 8–10 minutes. Let it boil gently for 3 minutes, continuing to stir.

In a small bowl, lightly beat the large eggs (or egg yolks). Slowly whisk about 1/2 cup of the hot mixture into the egg to temper it, then pour the tempered egg back into the double boiler, whisking constantly.
Cook over the simmering water for an additional 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the filling is thick and smooth.
Remove from heat and stir in the unsalted butter or butter until melted and fully incorporated.
Let the filling cool for about 10–15 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent a skin from forming. When slightly cooled, stir in the vanilla extract.
Pour the vanilla filling into the cooled, baked pie shell. Smooth the top with a spatula.

If topping with meringue: Spread the meringue over the filling while the filling is still warm, sealing the edges to the crust. Bake at 300°F (150°C) for 15–20 minutes until the meringue is lightly golden. Let cool completely before slicing.
If topping with whipped cream: Refrigerate the pie until fully set (at least 3 hours or overnight), then top with whipped cream just before serving.
Store leftovers covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

recipes.name: Lemon Meringue Pie
ingredients: 3/4 cup Egg yolks or large eggs (about 4 egg yolks)
1/4 cup Fresh lemon juice (from about 2 lemons)
instructions: Prepare the lemon filling: In a medium saucepan, whisk together the 1 1/2 cups sugar and cornstarch.
Gradually stir in the 1 1/2 cups boiling water. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens and comes to a boil.
Transfer the mixture to the top of a double boiler set over simmering water. Cook for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
In a small bowl, lightly beat the egg yolks or large eggs. Slowly whisk about 1/2 cup of the hot sugar mixture into the eggs to temper them.
Pour the tempered egg mixture back into the double boiler, whisking constantly. Cook for 5 more minutes, stirring constantly, until thick.
Remove from heat. Stir in the unsalted butter, lemon juice, and lemon zest until the unsalted butter is melted and everything is well combined.
Let the filling cool for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally. Pour into the cooled, pre-baked pie shell. Set aside while you make the meringue.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Make the meringue: In a clean, dry bowl, beat the egg whites with an electric mixer until foamy. Add the cream of tartar.

Continue beating on high speed until soft peaks form. Gradually add the 6 tablespoons sugar, one tablespoon at a time, beating constantly until stiff, glossy peaks form. The meringue should stand up straight when the beaters are lifted.
Spread the meringue over the warm (not hot) lemon filling, making sure to seal the meringue all the way to the edge of the crust. This prevents shrinking. Swirl or create peaks for a decorative look.
Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until the meringue is golden brown on the peaks.
Cool the pie at room temperature for 1 hour, then refrigerate for at least 3 hours before serving. The filling needs to set completely.
Serve chilled. Store any leftovers covered in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

recipes.name: Chocolate Oat-Chip Cookies
ingredients: 2 1/2 cups, uncooked Old-fashioned or quick oats
2 cups (12 oz package) Semi-sweet chocolate chips
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
In a large bowl, beat the softened unsalted butter with both sugars until light and creamy.
Add the eggs, milk, and vanilla, and beat until well combined.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix until just combined.
Stir in the oats, chocolate chips, and nuts (if using) until evenly distributed.
Drop dough by rounded tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets, spacing about 2 inches apart.
Bake for 9-10 minutes for chewy cookies, or 12-13 minutes for crisp cookies. The edges should be lightly golden.
Let cookies cool on the baking sheet for 1 minute, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
Store in an airtight container for up to 1 week.

recipes.name: Ginger Cookies
ingredients: about 1/2 cup Granulated sugar for rolling
instructions: In a large bowl, cream together the unsalted butter and 1 cup sugar until light and fluffy.
Beat in the egg and molasses until well combined.
In a separate bowl, sift together the flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, and ginger.
Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, mixing until just combined.
Cover the dough and refrigerate for at least 1 hour, or until firm enough to handle.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or coat with nonstick spray.
Shape the chilled dough into balls about 1 1/2 inches in diameter. Roll each ball in granulated sugar to coat.
Place the balls 3 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets.
Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until the edges are set and the tops are slightly cracked. The centers will still be soft.
Let cookies cool on the baking sheet for 2 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

recipes.name: Oatmeal Raisin Spice Cookies
ingredients: 2 1/2 cups, uncooked Old-fashioned or quick oats
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
In a large bowl, beat the softened unsalted butter with both sugars until light and creamy.
Add the eggs, milk, and vanilla, and beat until well combined.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, cinnamon, nutmeg, baking soda, and salt.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix until just combined.
Stir in the oats, raisins, and nuts (if using) until evenly distributed.
Drop dough by rounded tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets, spacing about 2 inches apart.
Bake for 9-10 minutes for chewy cookies, or 12-13 minutes for crisp cookies. The edges should be lightly golden.
Let cookies cool on the baking sheet for 2 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
Store in an airtight container for up to 1 week.

recipes.name: Lemon Squares
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly grease an 8x8x2-inch baking pan or coat with nonstick spray.
For the crust: In a small bowl, blend together the flour, powdered sugar, ground almonds, and softened unsalted butter until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Press the crust mixture evenly onto the bottom of the prepared pan.
Bake for 20 minutes, or until the crust is lightly golden around the edges.

Meanwhile, prepare the filling: In a medium bowl, beat the eggs with a mixer at medium speed until light. Add the sugar, lemon zest, lemon juice, baking powder, and salt. Beat for about 3 minutes until fluffy and well combined.
If using coconut, fold it into the filling mixture.
Pour the filling over the hot baked crust, spreading it evenly.
Return to the oven and bake for an additional 25 minutes, or until the filling is set and the top is golden brown.
Cool completely in the pan on a wire rack.
Once cooled, cut into 2-inch squares. Dust lightly with powdered sugar before serving, if desired.
Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.

recipes.name: Memory Book Cookies
ingredients: 2 cups, firmly packed Light brown sugar
instructions: In a large bowl, beat the softened unsalted butter at medium speed. Gradually add the brown sugar, beating until light and fluffy.
Add the eggs and vanilla, and mix well.
In a separate bowl, combine the flour, baking soda, and salt.
Gradually add the dry ingredients to the creamed mixture, mixing until well combined.
Stir in the chopped nuts.
Divide the dough in half. Shape each half into a 16-inch long roll (about 2 inches in diameter).
Wrap each roll tightly in waxed paper or plastic wrap, and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight. The dough can also be frozen for up to 3 months.
When ready to bake, preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Unwrap the chilled dough and cut into 1/3-inch slices using a sharp knife.
Place the slices on ungreased cookie sheets, spacing them about 1 inch apart.
Bake for 6-8 minutes, or until the edges are lightly golden. Do not overbake.
Cool on the baking sheets for 1 minute, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely.
Store in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

recipes.name: Springerle (Preferred Recipe)
ingredients: 10 drops (or 1 teaspoon anise extract) Anise oil
from 1 lemon, finely grated Lemon zest
2-3 tablespoons (optional) Crushed anise seeds (for sprinkling on pan)
instructions: Sift the flour with the baking soda and set aside.
In a large bowl with an electric mixer, beat the eggs until very light and frothy, about 5 minutes.
Add the powdered sugar a tablespoon at a time, continuing to beat constantly. Beat for at least 15 minutes total, until the mixture is thick and resembles a soft meringue.
Add the anise oil and grated lemon zest, and mix well.
Gradually blend in the sifted flour mixture, mixing until a soft dough forms.
Cover the dough tightly and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
Lightly flour a work surface. Roll out a small portion of the dough at a time to 1/4-inch thickness.
Press a floured springerle mold (or rolling pin with designs) firmly into the dough to create embossed patterns.
Cut the cookies apart along the design lines.

Place the cookies on ungreased, flat trays or baking sheets. Cover with a clean kitchen towel and let them dry at room temperature overnight (12-24 hours). This drying step is important for the characteristic hard texture.
The next day, preheat oven to 300°F (150°C).
Lightly coat cookie sheets with nonstick spray and sprinkle with crushed anise seeds if desired.
Transfer the dried cookies to the prepared cookie sheets.
Bake for 10-15 minutes. The cookies should remain pale; do not let them brown.
Cool on wire racks. Store in airtight containers. Springerle improve with age and can be stored for several weeks.

recipes.name: Ginger Snaps
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or coat lightly with nonstick spray.
In a small bowl, whisk together the vegetable oil and molasses until well combined.
In a large bowl, sift together the flour, brown sugar, ginger, cinnamon, cloves, baking soda, and salt.
Pour the molasses mixture into the dry ingredients and stir until a smooth, cohesive dough forms.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to 1/8-inch thickness.
Cut into small rounds (about 2 inches in diameter) using a cookie cutter.
Place the cookies on the prepared baking sheets, spacing them about 1 inch apart.
Bake for 15-18 minutes, or until the cookies are crisp and the edges are just beginning to darken.
Cool on the baking sheets for 2 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely. Store in an airtight container.

recipes.name: Lemon Snaps
ingredients: 2 tablespoons, finely grated Fresh lemon zest (from about 2 lemons)
2 tablespoons Fresh lemon juice or lemon extract
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or coat lightly with nonstick spray.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the corn syrup, vegetable oil, lemon zest, and lemon juice or extract until smooth and well combined.
In a separate bowl, sift together the flour, baking soda, and salt.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir until a smooth dough forms.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to 1/8-inch thickness.
Using a small round cookie cutter (about 2 inches), cut out cookies and place them on the prepared baking sheets, spacing them about 1 inch apart.
Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the cookies are lightly golden and crisp around the edges.
Cool on the baking sheets for 2 minutes, then carefully transfer to wire racks to cool completely. Store in an airtight container.

recipes.name: Brown Sugar Brownies
instructions: Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C). Lightly coat a 9x13-inch baking sheet or jelly roll pan with nonstick spray.
In a medium bowl, cream together the brown sugar and unsalted butter or butter until light and fluffy.
Beat in the egg and vanilla until well combined.
In a small bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture and mix until just combined.
Fold in the chopped pecans.
Spread the batter in a thin, even layer on the prepared baking sheet.
Bake for 18-20 minutes, or until the edges are set and lightly golden.
Remove from oven and cut into bars while still warm.
Cool completely on the pan before removing.

recipes.name: Sugar Cookies (Alice Carle's)
instructions: In a large bowl, cream together the powdered sugar and softened unsalted butter until light and fluffy.
Beat in the egg, vanilla, and almond extract until well combined.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, cream of tartar, and salt.
Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, mixing until a soft dough forms.
Wrap the dough tightly in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 2-3 hours, or overnight. This makes the dough easier to roll and helps the cookies hold their shape.
When ready to bake, preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or coat lightly with nonstick spray.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the chilled dough to your desired thickness (1/4 inch for crisp cookies, 1/2 inch for softer cookies).
Cut into desired shapes using cookie cutters. Place on prepared baking sheets, spacing about 1 inch apart.
Bake for 10-11 minutes, or until the edges are just barely golden. Do not overbake; the cookies should remain pale.
Cool on the baking sheets for 2 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely. Decorate with icing or sprinkles if desired.

recipes.name: Sugar Cookies (Preferred)
ingredients: 1 cup Granulated sugar (plus extra for sprinkling)
instructions: In a medium bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.
In a large bowl, cream the unsalted butter and 1 cup sugar together until light and fluffy.
Beat in the eggs and vanilla until well combined.
Gradually add the sifted dry ingredients to the creamed mixture, alternating with the milk, mixing until a dough forms.
If the dough is too soft to roll, wrap it in plastic and refrigerate for 30 minutes to 1 hour.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or coat lightly with nonstick spray.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to your desired thickness (about 1/4 inch for crisp cookies).
Cut into various shapes using cookie cutters and place on prepared baking sheets, spacing about 1 inch apart.
Sprinkle the tops of the cookies lightly with granulated sugar.
Bake for 12 minutes, or until the edges are lightly golden.
Cool on the baking sheets for 2 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely.

recipes.name: Sugar Cookies (Zuckerkuchen)
instructions: In a large bowl, cream together the sugar and unsalted butter until light and fluffy.
Beat in the eggs and mix well.
In a separate bowl, combine the flour, baking soda, and salt.
In a small bowl or measuring cup, combine the buttermilk, vanilla extract, and lemon extract.

Add the dry ingredients and the flavored milk to the creamed mixture in stages: add about 1/3 of the dry ingredients, mix well, then add about 1/3 of the milk mixture, and mix well. Repeat until all ingredients are incorporated. The dough should be smooth and pliable.
If the dough is too soft, wrap in plastic and refrigerate for 30 minutes to 1 hour.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or coat lightly with nonstick spray.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to 1/4-inch thickness (or thicker if you prefer softer cookies).
Cut into various shapes using cookie cutters. Place on prepared baking sheets, spacing about 1 inch apart.
Bake for 10-11 minutes, or until the edges are just barely golden. Do not overbake.
Cool on the baking sheets for 2 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely. These cookies are perfect for decorating with icing!

recipes.name: Liebkuchen (German Spiced Honey Cookies)
ingredients: 2 teaspoons Hartshorn (baker's ammonia) or baking powder (hartshorn for traditional flavor)
1/2 cup (4 oz) Sherry or red wine
1 pound (about 4 cups) Pecans or mixed nuts (chopped)
1/4 pound (about 1/2 cup) Citron (finely chopped candied citron)
instructions: In a very large bowl, combine the flour, sugar, cinnamon, cloves, allspice, and hartshorn (or baking powder). Mix well and make a well in the center.
Pour the honey, sherry (or wine), orange zest, and lemon zest into the well. Stir to begin combining.
In a food processor or grinder, finely grind the nuts and citron together. Add this mixture to the honey-flour mixture.
Mix by hand, kneading until all ingredients are well blended into a stiff dough. This may take some time and effort.
Cover the dough tightly and let it stand at room temperature overnight. This resting period allows the flavors to meld.
The next day, preheat oven to 325°F (165°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or coat lightly with nonstick spray.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to 1/4-inch thickness. Cut into diamond shapes (traditional) or use cookie cutters.
Place the cookies on prepared baking sheets, spacing about 1 inch apart.
Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until lightly browned. Do not overbake; the cookies should remain soft initially and will firm up as they cool.
Cool on wire racks. If desired, glaze with a simple powdered sugar icing while still slightly warm, or leave plain.
Store in an airtight container. These cookies improve with age and can be stored for several weeks.

recipes.name: Pfeffernusse (Pepper Nuts)
ingredients: 1 to 2 teaspoons Black pepper (use 2 tsp for extra spicy)
instructions: In a large bowl, beat the eggs slightly. Add 1 pound powdered sugar and the melted unsalted butter.
Mix with an electric mixer for 15 minutes, or beat by hand for 30 minutes. The mixture should be very light and fluffy.
In a separate bowl, combine the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, cloves, and black pepper.
Add the dry ingredients to the egg mixture one tablespoon at a time, mixing well after each addition. This gradual incorporation ensures a smooth dough.
Once all dry ingredients are incorporated, the dough should be stiff but pliable.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to 1/4-inch thickness.
Cut into small rounds, about 1 1/4 inches in diameter. These are traditional "pepper nuts" - small and round.
Preheat oven to 300°F (150°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or coat lightly with nonstick spray.
Place the cookies on prepared baking sheets and bake for about 20 minutes, or until slightly browned.
While the cookies are still warm, prepare the glaze: Mix 2 cups powdered sugar with 3-4 tablespoons boiling water and 1/2 teaspoon vanilla until smooth.
Brush or drizzle the glaze over the warm cookies, or dip each cookie into the glaze.
Let the glaze set completely before storing. These cookies keep well and are traditional German Christmas treats.

recipes.name: Gingerbread Men Cookies
ingredients: 5 to 6 cups All-purpose flour (additional, for stiff dough)
instructions: Early in the day (or up to 2 days ahead): In a large bowl, combine the brown sugar, softened unsalted butter, eggs, molasses, 3 cups flour, baking soda, salt, and all the spices (cinnamon, ginger, allspice, cloves).
Beat with an electric mixer on low speed until just mixed, then increase to medium speed and beat for 2 more minutes.
Using a wooden spoon, gradually stir in 5 to 6 additional cups of flour until the dough is very stiff and no longer sticky. You may need the full 6 cups.
Divide the dough in half and wrap each half tightly in plastic wrap. Refrigerate for at least 2 hours, or up to 2 days.
When ready to bake, preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
Working with one half of the dough at a time (keep the other half refrigerated), roll out on a lightly floured surface to 1/8-inch thickness.
Cut out gingerbread men shapes using a cookie cutter. Use a spatula to carefully transfer to prepared baking sheets.
Bake for 12 minutes, or until the edges are firm and the cookies are set. Do not overbake.
Cool on the baking sheets for 2 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely.
Decorate with royal icing, raisins, candies, or leave plain. Store in an airtight container.

recipes.name: Springerle (Carle Recipe)
ingredients: from 1 lemon Fresh lemon zest (finely grated)
10 drops Anise oil (or 1 tsp anise extract)
instructions: In a large bowl with an electric mixer, beat the eggs and powdered sugar together for at least 15 minutes. The mixture should be very thick, pale, and fluffy, resembling a soft meringue.
Add the cooled melted unsalted butter, anise oil, and grated lemon zest. Mix well until fully incorporated.
Sift together the flour and baking powder. Add to the egg mixture and mix well until a smooth, firm dough forms.
Cover the dough and let it rest for 15-20 minutes to make it easier to roll.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to 3/8-inch thickness (slightly thicker than most cookies).
Press a floured springerle rolling pin or mold firmly into the dough to create the traditional embossed designs.
Cut the cookies apart along the design lines using a sharp knife or pastry wheel.
Place the cookies on lightly greased baking sheets or parchment paper. Leave space between them.
Cover with a clean kitchen towel and let the cookies stand at room temperature overnight (12-24 hours). This drying step creates the characteristic hard texture.
The next day, preheat oven to 325°F (165°C).
Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until the cookies are slightly browned on the bottom but still pale on top. Do not overbake.
Cool completely on wire racks. Do not ice these cookies; the anise flavor and embossed design are meant to shine on their own.
Store in airtight containers. Springerle improve with age and can be kept for several weeks. They will soften slightly over time.

recipes.name: Springerle (Carle Recipe)
ingredients: 1/2 teaspoon Anise oil (or 1 tablespoon anise extract)
from 1 lemon Fresh lemon zest (finely grated)
instructions: In a large bowl, beat the eggs with an electric mixer on high speed for about 15 minutes until very light, thick, and pale yellow.
Gradually add the powdered sugar, a few tablespoons at a time, beating constantly. Continue beating for at least 10 more minutes until the mixture is thick and resembles a soft meringue.
Sift the flour with the baking powder.
Add the anise oil and grated lemon zest to the egg mixture and beat until incorporated.
Gently fold in the flour mixture with a spatula until just combined. Do not overmix.
Cover the dough and refrigerate for at least 1 hour or overnight.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out a portion of the chilled dough to 1/4-inch thickness.
Press a floured springerle mold or rolling pin firmly into the dough to emboss the traditional designs.
Cut the cookies apart along the embossed lines using a sharp knife or pastry cutter.
Place cookies on ungreased baking sheets. Cover with a clean kitchen towel and let dry at room temperature overnight (12-24 hours). This step is essential for the characteristic hard texture.
The next day, preheat oven to 300°F (150°C).
Lightly grease cookie sheets and sprinkle with crushed anise seeds.
Transfer the dried cookies to the prepared sheets.
Bake for 12-15 minutes. The cookies should remain very pale; do not let them brown.
Cool on wire racks. Store in airtight containers. Springerle improve with age and can be stored for several weeks or even months.
Note: This is Caroline Nagel Carle's original recipe, a treasured family tradition.

recipes.name: Sugar Cookies (Alice Carle's)
instructions: In a large bowl, cream together the softened unsalted butter and sugar until light and fluffy.
Beat in the eggs one at a time, then add the vanilla extract and mix well.
In a separate bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, and salt.
Gradually add the dry ingredients to the creamed mixture, mixing until well combined.
Cover the dough and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or overnight.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the chilled dough to 1/8-inch thickness.
Cut out shapes with cookie cutters and place on prepared baking sheets about 1 inch apart.
Bake for 8-10 minutes, or until the edges are just beginning to turn golden.
Cool on baking sheets for 2 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely.
Decorate with frosting, sprinkles, or colored sugar if desired.
Note: This recipe was used by Alma Carle in the 1950s when the children were small.

recipes.name: Frosted Pineapple Squares
ingredients: 1 can (1 lb 14 oz) Pineapple chunks with juice
4 Egg yolks (room temperature (plus 1 extra yolk used in filling))
As needed Confectioners' sugar frosting (for drizzling over cooled squares)
instructions: Make the pineapple filling: In a medium saucepan, whisk together sugar, cornstarch, and salt. Stir in the pineapple (with its juice) and the milk.
Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture comes to a full boil and thickens to a spoon-coating consistency. Remove from heat and let cool to room temperature.
Make the dough sponge: In a large bowl, combine about 1 1/3 cups (160 g) of the flour, the 1 teaspoon sugar, and the dry yeast.

Warm the water and unsalted butter together until just warm to the touch (105–115°F / 40–46°C). Add to the flour-yeast mixture and beat on medium speed for 2–3 minutes, scraping the bowl occasionally.
Beat in the egg yolks and another 1/2 cup (60 g) of flour. Continue adding just enough of the remaining flour to form a soft, slightly sticky dough.
Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead 8–10 minutes, adding flour only as needed, until smooth and elastic.
Place the dough in a lightly greased bowl, turn to coat, cover, and let rise in a warm, draft-free place until doubled, about 1 hour.
Lightly grease a jelly-roll pan (about 10x15 in / 25x38 cm). Divide the dough in half. Roll one half to fit the bottom of the pan and transfer it to the pan.
Spread the cooled pineapple filling evenly over the dough in the pan.
Roll the remaining dough to the same size and place over the filling. Pinch edges to seal and snip the top in several places with scissors to allow steam to escape.
Cover and let rise again until puffy, 30–45 minutes.
Near the end of rising, preheat the oven to 350–375°F (175–190°C).
Bake 25–35 minutes, or until the top is deep golden brown and the bread sounds hollow when tapped.
Cool completely in the pan. Drizzle with confectioners' sugar frosting and cut into squares to serve.

recipes.name: Cranberry Orange Relish
ingredients: 12-16 ounces (1 package) Fresh or frozen cranberries (about 3-4 cups)
instructions: Rinse the cranberries and pick over to remove any stems or soft berries.
Scrub the orange well. Cut it into 8 wedges and remove any seeds, but leave the peel on.
If using a food processor: Pulse the cranberries and orange wedges together until finely chopped but not pureed. If using a meat grinder: Grind the cranberries and orange wedges through the grinder.
Transfer the mixture to a bowl and stir in sugar to taste, starting with 3/4 cup and adding more if you prefer it sweeter.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 2-3 days before serving to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve as a condiment with turkey, chicken, or ham. Keeps refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.

recipes.name: Ice Box Pickles
instructions: Scrub the cucumbers well and cut into 1/2-inch chunks, or leave whole if small.

Dissolve 1/4 cup pickling salt in 6 cups water. Pour over cucumbers in a large bowl or crock. Place a plate on top and weigh it down to keep cucumbers submerged. Let sit at room temperature for 4 days.
Drain and rinse the cucumbers well.
Dissolve 1 tablespoon alum in enough water to cover the cucumbers. Cover and refrigerate overnight.
Drain and rinse again. Place cucumbers in a clean container and cover with about 4 cups white vinegar. Let soak for 6 hours.
Drain the vinegar (you can save it for another use).
In a large crock or container, layer the cucumber chunks with the sugar and pickling spices. Stir and turn occasionally until all the sugar dissolves.
Cover and refrigerate. The pickles will be ready to eat in 2-3 days and will keep refrigerated for several weeks.

recipes.name: Kool-Aid Jelly
ingredients: 1 packet (0.13-0.16 oz) Unsweetened Kool-Aid drink mix (any flavor)
instructions: Sterilize 3 half-pint jelly jars and lids by boiling them in water for 10 minutes. Keep hot until ready to use.
Pour 3 cups of water into a large saucepan. Stir in the Kool-Aid powder and Sure-Jell until completely dissolved.
Bring the mixture to a rolling boil over high heat, stirring constantly.
Add all 3 cups of sugar at once. Stir constantly and bring back to a full rolling boil.
Boil hard for 1 minute, stirring constantly.
Remove from heat and skim off any foam from the surface.
Quickly ladle the hot jelly into the hot sterilized jars, leaving 1/4-inch headspace.
Wipe the rims clean, seal with lids and rings, and let cool. The jelly will set as it cools.
Store in the refrigerator for up to 3 weeks, or process in a boiling water bath for 5 minutes for shelf-stable storage.
